story:
Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. 150,000 people suffer from vascular dementia in this country and one of them was my Grandma who died on 3 January 2021. British Heart Foundation are doing research into who is at risk from this disease. The British Heart Foundation says “this work could help doctors better detect cognitive problems and help them decide on the best care for each individual patient.” 

I am going to walk 150 miles over the next few weeks- 1 mile  for each 1000 people with vascular dementia. This will be my volunteering part of my Duke of Edinburgh Bronze Award.

This next year I'm not going to stop.

So please give generously to the wonderful British Heart Foundation, who have done so much and will continue to do so for those suffering from cardiovascular diseases.

story:
The global pandemic is the biggest challenge the BHF has faced in it's 60 year history.  Despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers.  We eat too much sugar, it's bad for your heart, so we're giving up for March!

In March 2019 Ben suffered a heart attack and out of hospital cardiac arrest whilst on duty as a Police Officer. In addition, on arrival at hospital he suffered a lung haemorrhage causing a second cardiac arrest.  We were told that night that it was unlikely he would recover and we should say goodbye.  By some miracle, the wonderful care of the NHS and, I believe, the pure strength and determination of this incredible man, Ben began to recover, he opened his eyes 4 days later and from then on made slow and steady recovery.

During his 6 weeks in intensive care he also overcame a tracheostomy, kidney failure, pneumonia, sepsis  and  having numerous blood transfusions.  He learnt to walk and talk again and built his muscle strength back up. We were told that he would almost certainly have suffered some form of brain damage as a result.  The brain scan said different, very minimal signs of any damage.  Ben sometimes struggles with short term memory and has been known to substitute some words for very bizarre alternatives but we are truly grateful for that!  Against all odds he is back on the beat as a full time response officer.

The BHF do amazing work.  It's time we gave something back.

If you can spare even £1 we would be hugely grateful, we appreciate you all, and we appreciate how precious life is too.

Peace and love, Caroline x

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: NA
rememberedPersonSummary.name: Malcolm Phillips
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story:
In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation.

Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss.

We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society.

A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

New year and our third attempt at taking on a challenge to raise more funds for GOSH. As many of you will know we initially signed up for the Peak District Challenge scheduled for July 2020 which due to Covid had to be cancelled. We then changed to the Jurassic Coast Challenge for September 2020 but sadly this too was cancelled. And so we're trying again in the hope that our event in May - virus permitting - will get the go ahead. Fingers crossed!

We're truly grateful to all those (22 supporters in total who are listed in our original GOSH JustGiving page: https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising-edit/teampurbrun) who donated in 2020 even though we didn't set off and would like to assure you that the incredible sum of £770 raised as part of our £1,000 target has been put to good use. It has ensured that Great Ormond Street Hospital during these most challenging of times has been able to continue its great work and, more importantly for our family, has continued to treat, support and care for our two "junior" members, now aged 9 and 7. They thankfully continue to grow, flourish and enjoy life.

Anyway to help get us started on a training regime we are taking part in a virtual challenge, namely, walking the Welsh Coastal Path, Chepstow to Chester, 870 miles!!! We have a year to complete this particular challenge and are accompanied by Zoë, Pete's daughter, and Evelyn, our 1 year old granddaughter, who are making sure we keep to a strict regime. We are using it as a means to clock up the mileage and stamina we'll need to do the 26.2 miles we'll be doing from Weymouth to Bridport on Sunday 16 May 2021.

We'll let you know how we progress, you can follow us here: https://www.endtoend.run/map-wcp3/ by typing 'Pete Browne' into the 'search for names' box, we're Bib number 39228 ..... Thanks for reading. Stay safe and take care.

story:
The ‘C’ word is something that has affected so many families lives, including my own and I want to do my bit to support those who need it most. 

Cancer has been in my family a lot, and I am so proud to say my Mum is a survivor of breast cancer and put up an incredible fight! 

My Dad has recently been diagnosed with cancer and is preparing for the fight of his life, but with all of our love and support and the amazing work that all of the hospitals and cancer nurses will provide, we know he will come out the other side even stronger! 

Please donate as little or as much as you can to help me support the families like mine who are having to show Cancer who is boss!! I am doing this for everyone who has ever been affected by cancer and for my friends and family who are on one of the toughest journeys - remember, you have cancer, cancer hasn’t got you!!

As you will all agree, Gran was a wonderful woman. She always had a smile on her face and was full of love. As some of you may be aware, Gran overcame breast cancer when she was younger and ever since has been a strong supporter of Cancer Research UK, she made regular donations and also volunteered in one of their stores for several years. pageSummary: Completing a solo Ironman because they need our support
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Lockdown Ironman

Back in the autumn I was looking for a physical challenge for 2021 - I needed something self masochistic to relieve the stress of COVID and work. The Sussexman triathlon or Lockdown Ironman was born.

The idea is simple, and Ironman distance triathlon (3.8k swim, 112 mile cycle, 26 mile run) starting in the sea at Brighton, riding over the South Downs, and then a marathon from Hampton court in central London and finishing at Big Ben.

Of course, it’s all got to be socially distanced, so I’ll be doing it solo, but supported through the different stages by friends from Mid Sussex Triathlon Club, some swimming, others cycling and some running. The race is scheduled for Saturday 19th June.

The plan is to raise a little money along the way. I will be fundraising for the RLNI - lifeboats. We all expect them to ‘just be there’ when we get into trouble like all the other emergency services, but they are charity made up of volunteers and facing all the same COVID challenges. The more crazy people like me who take to sea swimming the more they are going to be in demand, so I would like to give something back. So please donate whenever and whatever you can.

Best wishes. Adam

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Me and my sister were going to go to Wales and Scotland but we could not go because of lockdown. So we thought that if we could not go to see the mountains then why couldn't the mountains come to us. Now I plan to scale Ben Nevis and my sister wants to climb Mount Snowdon all from the comfort of our own home.

On the 31st of January I plan to climb 587 flights of stairs (the height of Ben Nevis) in 24 hours and my sister plans to climb 475 flights of stairs (the height of Mount Snowdon). Both of us wanting to say we climbed to the top of a mountain but from the comfort of our own home. But most important of all is helping the children in Yemen by supporting the work UNICEF is doing. So please donate!

story:
Covid-19 has effect us all incredibly hard both at home and abroad but it's easy to forget what those in already horrific circumstances are going through. 

From intersect civilians and refugees being involved in wars that they don't deserve to be a part of to humanitarian crisis around the globe.

Children across the globe deserve better and don't deserve to be brought up in war zones, nor should they go without fresh water and nor should any child go hungry.

It was was tough for me to decide what charity to do these series of challenges for as all are so important both here at home in the UK and abroad.

Over the Space of 7 months i will be taking part of what I've called, the "BTEC Olympics" 
Unlike the real Olympics there will be no athletes, only myself (The garage dweller) 

7 Challenges have been spread throughout 7 months, from March 1st to September 31st.

March: 500Km Run to be covered over the space of a month.
April: 3,000Km Cycle to be covered over the space of a month.
May: National 3 Peak Challenge (Coivd allowing) 
June: 24 Hour Turbo Challenge.
July: TBC
August: TBC
September: TBC


I'll be documenting every step of the way to ensure that all the challenges are completed.

If anyone wants to take part and join me to challenge themselves this year i'd strongly advise doing so.


If you reading this, thank you ever so much for your time and i hope you consider donating.




Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.
